Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the potential harm of the Covid-19 vaccine by stating that it will kill individuals who take it.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or scientific support to back up the assertion that the vaccine will cause death.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the Covid-19 vaccine is part of a conspiracy to sell Sri Lanka to foreigners, which is a problematic assumption without any credible evidence.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the Sri Lankan government has approved the emergency use of the vaccine and is planning a mass vaccination drive.
Understate: The claim understates the importance of vaccination in controlling the spread of Covid-19, as stated by medical experts.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores alternative explanations for the increase in Covid-19 cases, such as the lack of effective preventive measures or the endorsement of unproven herbal treatments by Sri Lankan health officials.
Falters at times: The claim falters by promoting alternative remedies like boiled coriander seeds and ginger as a cure for Covid-19, which is not supported by scientific evidence.
